<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1/2-<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>, i<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>].</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

(d) Crystal packing diagram of 3D supramolecular network, assembled by hydrogen bonding interactions. [Symmetry codes: A=-x, -y, -z; B=-x, 1/2-+y, 1/2-z; C= x, 1/2-y, 1/2+ z, i=2- x, 1- y, 1- z].

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">A new flexible 3D supramolecular framework, [Co(4,4′-bipy)(pro)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (4,4′-bipy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-bipyridine and pro<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>propionate) has been prepared and structurally characterized. This compound crystallizes in monoclinic, space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/c. Each Co(II) cation shows an octahedral geometry. The Co(II) ions are assembled by the bridging propionate and 4,4′-bipyridine ligands in <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axes, generating an infinite 2D layer. These 2D layer networks are further linked to one another by hydrogen bonding interactions, leading to a 3D supramolecular framework. Interestingly, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits water-induced reversible crystal-to-amorphous transformation with chromotropism confirmed by spectroscopic techniques, elemental analysis, TGA, and XRPD. Thus, dehydrated amorphous form, Co(4,4′-bipy)(pro)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1A</ce:bold>), may be utilized as an indicator for humidity.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new flexible 3D supramolecular framework, [Co(4,4'-bipy)(pro)2(H2O)] (1) (4,4'-bipy=4,4'-bipyridine and pro=propionate) has been prepared and structurally characterized. This compound crystallizes in monoclinic, space group P21/c. Each Co(II) cation shows an octahedral geometry. The Co(II) ions are assembled by the bridging propionate and 4,4'-bipyridine ligands in c and a axes, generating an infinite 2D layer. These 2D layer networks are further linked to one another by hydrogen bonding interactions, leading to a 3D supramolecular framework. Interestingly, compound 1 exhibits water-induced reversible crystal-to-amorphous transformation with chromotropism confirmed by spectroscopic techniques, elemental analysis, TGA, and XRPD. Thus, dehydrated amorphous form, Co(4,4'-bipy)(pro)2 (1A), may be utilized as an indicator for humidity.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0010">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">A new flexible 3D supramolecular framework, [Co(4,4′-bipy)(pro)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>); 4,4′-bipy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-bipyridine and pro<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>propionate has been synthesized and fully characterized. This compound exhibits a water-induced reversible crystal-to-amorphous transformation with chromotropism.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:link id="lk0015" locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A new flexible 3D supramolecular framework, [Co(4,4'-bipy)(pro)2(H2O)] (1); 4,4'-bipy=4,4'-bipyridine and pro=propionate has been synthesized and fully characterized. This compound exhibits a water-induced reversible crystal-to-amorphous transformation with chromotropism.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0040" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="u0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">A new 2D Co(II) coordination framework (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) has been synthesized.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows flexible 3D supramolecular architecture via interlayer hydrogen bonds.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a reversible crystal-to-amorphous transformation with chromotropism.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0020">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">This functional property is water-induced behavior.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ A new 2D Co(II) coordination framework (1) has been synthesized.   ⋅  1 shows flexible 3D supramolecular architecture via interlayer hydrogen bonds.   ⋅  1 exhibits a reversible crystal-to-amorphous transformation with chromotropism.   ⋅ This functional property is water-induced behavior.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">A new 2D Co(II) coordination framework (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) has been synthesized.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows flexible 3D supramolecular architecture via interlayer hydrogen bonds.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a reversible crystal-to-amorphous transformation with chromotropism.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">This functional property is water-induced behavior.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The construction of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is currently attracting considerable attention because of their intriguing molecular topologies and crystal packing motifs, along with their potential applications such as adsorption, separation, ion exchange, catalysis, magnetism, optics, and electrical conductivity . One of the important properties of MOFs is the framework flexibility which exhibits solid-state structural transformations with breaking, making, or rearrangement of bonds driven by chemical stimuli . The structural transformations are generally accompanied by removal or exchange of guest, changes in coordination number of metal containing nodes, and conformational changes in flexible parts of organic ligands . The water-induced structural reversible transformation is typically found in the dynamic and flexible coordination frameworks supported by weak intermolecular interactions, such as hydrogen bonds, π–π stacking, van der Waals forces, and others. Therefore, the solvent molecules may also play a key role by acting as an essential support to the structure of the host framework and it is important for expanding the field of crystal engineering by controlling the weak interaction of MOFs .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
A new 2D Co(II) coordination framework (1) has been synthesized.

 1 shows flexible 3D supramolecular architecture via interlayer hydrogen bonds.

 1 exhibits a reversible crystal-to-amorphous transformation with chromotropism.

This functional property is water-induced behavior.

The construction of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is currently attracting considerable attention because of their intriguing molecular topologies and crystal packing motifs, along with their potential applications such as adsorption, separation, ion exchange, catalysis, magnetism, optics, and electrical conductivity . One of the important properties of MOFs is the framework flexibility which exhibits solid-state structural transformations with breaking, making, or rearrangement of bonds driven by chemical stimuli . The structural transformations are generally accompanied by removal or exchange of guest, changes in coordination number of metal containing nodes, and conformational changes in flexible parts of organic ligands . The water-induced structural reversible transformation is typically found in the dynamic and flexible coordination frameworks supported by weak intermolecular interactions, such as hydrogen bonds, π-π stacking, van der Waals forces, and others. Therefore, the solvent molecules may also play a key role by acting as an essential support to the structure of the host framework and it is important for expanding the field of crystal engineering by controlling the weak interaction of MOFs .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">From our previous work, the reversible thermal dehydration and rehydration of 1D coordination framework [Co(3,5-pydc)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>; 3,5-pydc<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3,5-pyridinedicarboxylate have been reported . The reversibility is driven by strong hydrogen bonding between guest water and coordinated water molecules and other components. Without guest water like a 2D coordination network [Co(3,5-pydc)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>, the irreversibility is observed. Herein, we report the contradictory case, the highly stable 3D supramolecular framework [Co(4,4′-bipy)(pro)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). Its 2D coordination layers are assembled by hydrogen bonding interactions, leading to a 3D supramolecular framework. This compound shows a reversible crystal-to-amorphous transformation upon desorption and resorption processes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: From our previous work, the reversible thermal dehydration and rehydration of 1D coordination framework [Co(3,5-pydc)(H2O)4]n(H2O)n; 3,5-pydc=3,5-pyridinedicarboxylate have been reported . The reversibility is driven by strong hydrogen bonding between guest water and coordinated water molecules and other components. Without guest water like a 2D coordination network [Co(3,5-pydc)(H2O)2]n, the irreversibility is observed. Herein, we report the contradictory case, the highly stable 3D supramolecular framework [Co(4,4'-bipy)(pro)2(H2O)] (1). Its 2D coordination layers are assembled by hydrogen bonding interactions, leading to a 3D supramolecular framework. This compound shows a reversible crystal-to-amorphous transformation upon desorption and resorption processes.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis shows that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a 2D coordination network. The asymmetric unit consists of one cobalt atom, one 4,4′-bipy ligand, two pro ligands, and one coordinated water molecule (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, and Fig. S1) . Each Co(II) ion exhibits a distorted octahedral geometry; the coordinate environment comprises of two O atoms from two different pro bridges, one O atom from water molecule and one O atom from a monodentate, terminal pro ligand, forming a square base (b, Fig. S1 and Table S1), while two axial positions of octahedron are completed by two N atoms from different 4,4′-bipy ligands (Table S1). These Co(II) ions are linked by the bridging 4,4′-bipy ligand (N(1) and N(2)) in <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis and the bridging pro ligand (O(3) and O(4)) along <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis, leading to an infinite 2D layer network (c and Fig. S2) leaving a water molecule and a remaining monodentate propionate as the terminal ligands in which both coordinated water and the uncoordinated O(2) of non-bridging propionate ligand are hydrogen-bonded (O(5)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H(6w)⋯O(2)) to one another (Fig. S3a). These 2D layers of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are linked to one another by strong interlayer hydrogen bonding among the uncoordinated O atom of the monodentate, terminal propionate ligands and H atoms of 4,4′-bipy ligand (C(2)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H(2)⋯O(2) and C(9)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H(7)⋯O(2)) with H⋯O distances of 2.481(19) and 2.364(19)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (see Table S2), leading to a 3D supramolecular framework (Fig. S3b).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis shows that compound 1 is a 2D coordination network. The asymmetric unit consists of one cobalt atom, one 4,4'-bipy ligand, two pro ligands, and one coordinated water molecule (a, and Fig. S1) . Each Co(II) ion exhibits a distorted octahedral geometry; the coordinate environment comprises of two O atoms from two different pro bridges, one O atom from water molecule and one O atom from a monodentate, terminal pro ligand, forming a square base (b, Fig. S1 and Table S1), while two axial positions of octahedron are completed by two N atoms from different 4,4'-bipy ligands (Table S1). These Co(II) ions are linked by the bridging 4,4'-bipy ligand (N(1) and N(2)) in a axis and the bridging pro ligand (O(3) and O(4)) along c axis, leading to an infinite 2D layer network (c and Fig. S2) leaving a water molecule and a remaining monodentate propionate as the terminal ligands in which both coordinated water and the uncoordinated O(2) of non-bridging propionate ligand are hydrogen-bonded (O(5)H(6w)⋯O(2)) to one another (Fig. S3a). These 2D layers of compound 1 are linked to one another by strong interlayer hydrogen bonding among the uncoordinated O atom of the monodentate, terminal propionate ligands and H atoms of 4,4'-bipy ligand (C(2)H(2)⋯O(2) and C(9)H(7)⋯O(2)) with H⋯O distances of 2.481(19) and 2.364(19)Å (see Table S2), leading to a 3D supramolecular framework (Fig. S3b).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">To assess the thermal stability, TGA was recorded for the single-phase polycrystalline samples in the temperature range of 30–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. During the heating process, the TGA profile of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicates the release of one coordinated water molecule at the first step of weight loss which is in the temperature range of 100–134<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (found, 3.81%; anal. calcd, 4.21%), resulting to the dehydrated form of Co(4,4′-bipy)(pro)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1A</ce:bold>), which is stable up to ≈<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>215<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and then the structure rapidly decomposes at higher temperature, as shown in Fig. S4.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To assess the thermal stability, TGA was recorded for the single-phase polycrystalline samples in the temperature range of 30-800°C. During the heating process, the TGA profile of 1 indicates the release of one coordinated water molecule at the first step of weight loss which is in the temperature range of 100-134°C (found, 3.81%; anal. calcd, 4.21%), resulting to the dehydrated form of Co(4,4'-bipy)(pro)2 (1A), which is stable up to ~215°C and then the structure rapidly decomposes at higher temperature, as shown in Fig. S4.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The dynamic structural behaviors of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> relating to their dehydration and rehydration processes are studied by elemental analyses, XRPD, and spectroscopic techniques. When the single crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were heated to 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in air for 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min, these crystals suddenly lose their crystallinity and the color changes from orange (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) to pink (<ce:bold>1A</ce:bold>). Then this non-crystalline solid was exposed to water vapor for 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h and the color of the solid <ce:bold>1A</ce:bold> was returned to that of the original crystals <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor> and Fig. S5. For this, the solid-state UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra as shown in Fig. S6, clearly show that the bands observed in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′ correspond very well to the identical transitions causing the same color of products, and evidence that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′ have the same Co(II) environments. This spectral feature agrees with the typical d–d transitions of high spin Co(II) in distorted octahedral geometry with two broad bands at 471 and 1180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, assigned to the ν<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>: <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>(P) and ν<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>: <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf>, transitions, respectively . Whereas the amorphous form <ce:bold>1A</ce:bold> shows different d–d transitions with three broad bands, ν<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>: <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>(P) which is splitted into two shoulders at around 484<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 518<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>E<ce:inf loc="post">g</ce:inf> and <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>A<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf>), ν<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>A<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf> at 656<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and then ν<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>: <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf> which is splitted into two shoulders at around 934<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 1337<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>B<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf> and <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>E<ce:inf loc="post">g</ce:inf>), giving the distinctive pink color and corresponding to the tetragonally distorted octahedral geometry . Furthermore, the IR spectra also confirm the structural transformation behavior in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, as shown in Fig S7. In <ce:bold>1A</ce:bold>, the broad and strong peaks of O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H stretching around 3300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and H<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H bending around 1500–1600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> of coordinated water molecule disappear, resulting to the sharper IR spectrum with different splitting feature and a shift in some peak positions. In contrast, these features are removed in the IR spectrum of the rehydrated form <ce:bold>1′</ce:bold>, which are identical to that of the as-synthesized <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The XRPD pattern of the as-synthesized product closely match the simulated one from the single-crystal data (Fig. S8). However, the XRPD pattern of dehydrated <ce:bold>1A</ce:bold> shows peak disappearance, indicating that the dehydrated Co(4,4′-bipy)(pro)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1A</ce:bold>) is in an amorphous phase (anal. calcd: C, 53.19; H, 5.02; N, 7.75%. Found: C, 52.26; H, 5.04; N, 7.61%) which is formed by the collapse of supramolecular structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> accompanied with the destruction of hydrogen bonding networks when all water molecules are removed. Interestingly, this amorphous phase <ce:bold>1A</ce:bold> can be restored to the original crystalline phase of <ce:bold>1′</ce:bold> in which the color returns to that of the original color after being exposed in water vapor for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, as indicated by elemental analysis with the chemical composition of [Co(4,4′-bipy)(pro)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′) (anal. calcd: C, 50.67; H, 5.32; N, 7.39%. Found: C, 50.34; H, 5.28; N, 7.42%) and the XRPD measurement results. The restored solid has the same XRPD pattern as the simulated one from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. This behavior was also investigated for other solvents vapor such as methanol, ethanol, acetone, acetonitrile, dichloromethane, DMF and DMSO, but sensitive only with water vapor.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The dynamic structural behaviors of 1 relating to their dehydration and rehydration processes are studied by elemental analyses, XRPD, and spectroscopic techniques. When the single crystals of 1 were heated to 150°C in air for 20min, these crystals suddenly lose their crystallinity and the color changes from orange (1) to pink (1A). Then this non-crystalline solid was exposed to water vapor for 12h and the color of the solid 1A was returned to that of the original crystals 1', as shown in   and Fig. S5. For this, the solid-state UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra as shown in Fig. S6, clearly show that the bands observed in 1 and 1' correspond very well to the identical transitions causing the same color of products, and evidence that 1 and 1' have the same Co(II) environments. This spectral feature agrees with the typical d-d transitions of high spin Co(II) in distorted octahedral geometry with two broad bands at 471 and 1180nm, assigned to the ν3: 4T1g → 4T1g(P) and ν1: 4T1g → 4T2g, transitions, respectively . Whereas the amorphous form 1A shows different d-d transitions with three broad bands, ν3: 4T1g → 4T1g(P) which is splitted into two shoulders at around 484nm and 518nm (4Eg and 4A2g), ν2: 4T1g → 4A2g at 656nm and then ν1: 4T1g → 4T2g which is splitted into two shoulders at around 934nm and 1337nm (4B2g and 4Eg), giving the distinctive pink color and corresponding to the tetragonally distorted octahedral geometry . Furthermore, the IR spectra also confirm the structural transformation behavior in 1, as shown in Fig S7. In 1A, the broad and strong peaks of OH stretching around 3300cm-1 and HOH bending around 1500-1600cm-1 of coordinated water molecule disappear, resulting to the sharper IR spectrum with different splitting feature and a shift in some peak positions. In contrast, these features are removed in the IR spectrum of the rehydrated form 1', which are identical to that of the as-synthesized 1. The XRPD pattern of the as-synthesized product closely match the simulated one from the single-crystal data (Fig. S8). However, the XRPD pattern of dehydrated 1A shows peak disappearance, indicating that the dehydrated Co(4,4'-bipy)(pro)2 (1A) is in an amorphous phase (anal. calcd: C, 53.19; H, 5.02; N, 7.75%. Found: C, 52.26; H, 5.04; N, 7.61%) which is formed by the collapse of supramolecular structure of 1 accompanied with the destruction of hydrogen bonding networks when all water molecules are removed. Interestingly, this amorphous phase 1A can be restored to the original crystalline phase of 1' in which the color returns to that of the original color after being exposed in water vapor for 24h, as indicated by elemental analysis with the chemical composition of [Co(4,4'-bipy)(pro)2(H2O)] (1') (anal. calcd: C, 50.67; H, 5.32; N, 7.39%. Found: C, 50.34; H, 5.28; N, 7.42%) and the XRPD measurement results. The restored solid has the same XRPD pattern as the simulated one from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of 1. This behavior was also investigated for other solvents vapor such as methanol, ethanol, acetone, acetonitrile, dichloromethane, DMF and DMSO, but sensitive only with water vapor.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">In the present case, although water molecule does not directly involve in the reversible crystal-to-amorphous transformation but induces the strong interlayer hydrogen bonding, after heating, water molecule is removed with the breaking of O(5)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H(6w)⋯O(2) hydrogen bonds in the layer (Fig. S3). This consequently breaks the strong interlayer hydrogen bonds (C(2)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H(2)⋯O(2) and C(9)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H(7)⋯O(2)) as the uncoordinated O(2) atom of terminal propionate group may move toward metal center for weak coordination, thus immediately destroying such hydrogen bonds between layers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the present case, although water molecule does not directly involve in the reversible crystal-to-amorphous transformation but induces the strong interlayer hydrogen bonding, after heating, water molecule is removed with the breaking of O(5)H(6w)⋯O(2) hydrogen bonds in the layer (Fig. S3). This consequently breaks the strong interlayer hydrogen bonds (C(2)H(2)⋯O(2) and C(9)H(7)⋯O(2)) as the uncoordinated O(2) atom of terminal propionate group may move toward metal center for weak coordination, thus immediately destroying such hydrogen bonds between layers.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">In summary, a new 2D coordination framework <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has been successfully prepared and structurally characterized. The layer networks are linked to one another by hydrogen bonds, leading to a 3D supramolecular framework. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits reversible structural transformation from the crystal form (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) to the amorphous powder (<ce:bold>1A</ce:bold>) with the color changes, triggered by the weak intermolecular interactions during the removal and restoration of water molecule. This work may have potential application as adsorbent material for moisture.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, a new 2D coordination framework 1 has been successfully prepared and structurally characterized. The layer networks are linked to one another by hydrogen bonds, leading to a 3D supramolecular framework. Compound 1 exhibits reversible structural transformation from the crystal form (1) to the amorphous powder (1A) with the color changes, triggered by the weak intermolecular interactions during the removal and restoration of water molecule. This work may have potential application as adsorbent material for moisture.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">To assess the thermal stability, TGA was recorded for the single-phase polycrystalline samples in the temperature range of 30–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. During the heating process, the TGA profile of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicates the release of one coordinated water molecule at the first step of weight loss which is in the temperature range of 100–134<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (found, 3.81%; anal. calcd, 4.21%), resulting to the dehydrated form of Co(4,4′-bipy)(pro)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1A</ce:bold>), which is stable up to ≈<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>215<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and then the structure rapidly decomposes at higher temperature, as shown in Fig. S4.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The dynamic structural behaviors of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> relating to their dehydration and rehydration processes are studied by elemental analyses, XRPD, and spectroscopic techniques. When the single crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were heated to 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in air for 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min, these crystals suddenly lose their crystallinity and the color changes from orange (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) to pink (<ce:bold>1A</ce:bold>). Then this non-crystalline solid was exposed to water vapor for 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h and the color of the solid <ce:bold>1A</ce:bold> was returned to that of the original crystals <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor> and Fig. S5. For this, the solid-state UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra as shown in Fig. S6, clearly show that the bands observed in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′ correspond very well to the identical transitions causing the same color of products, and evidence that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′ have the same Co(II) environments. This spectral feature agrees with the typical d–d transitions of high spin Co(II) in distorted octahedral geometry with two broad bands at 471 and 1180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, assigned to the ν<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>: <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>(P) and ν<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>: <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf>, transitions, respectively . Whereas the amorphous form <ce:bold>1A</ce:bold> shows different d–d transitions with three broad bands, ν<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>: <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>(P) which is splitted into two shoulders at around 484<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 518<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>E<ce:inf loc="post">g</ce:inf> and <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>A<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf>), ν<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>A<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf> at 656<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and then ν<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>: <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf> which is splitted into two shoulders at around 934<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 1337<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>B<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf> and <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>E<ce:inf loc="post">g</ce:inf>), giving the distinctive pink color and corresponding to the tetragonally distorted octahedral geometry . Furthermore, the IR spectra also confirm the structural transformation behavior in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, as shown in Fig S7. In <ce:bold>1A</ce:bold>, the broad and strong peaks of O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H stretching around 3300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and H<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H bending around 1500–1600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> of coordinated water molecule disappear, resulting to the sharper IR spectrum with different splitting feature and a shift in some peak positions. In contrast, these features are removed in the IR spectrum of the rehydrated form <ce:bold>1′</ce:bold>, which are identical to that of the as-synthesized <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The XRPD pattern of the as-synthesized product closely match the simulated one from the single-crystal data (Fig. S8). However, the XRPD pattern of dehydrated <ce:bold>1A</ce:bold> shows peak disappearance, indicating that the dehydrated Co(4,4′-bipy)(pro)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1A</ce:bold>) is in an amorphous phase (anal. calcd: C, 53.19; H, 5.02; N, 7.75%. Found: C, 52.26; H, 5.04; N, 7.61%) which is formed by the collapse of supramolecular structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> accompanied with the destruction of hydrogen bonding networks when all water molecules are removed. Interestingly, this amorphous phase <ce:bold>1A</ce:bold> can be restored to the original crystalline phase of <ce:bold>1′</ce:bold> in which the color returns to that of the original color after being exposed in water vapor for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, as indicated by elemental analysis with the chemical composition of [Co(4,4′-bipy)(pro)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′) (anal. calcd: C, 50.67; H, 5.32; N, 7.39%. Found: C, 50.34; H, 5.28; N, 7.42%) and the XRPD measurement results. The restored solid has the same XRPD pattern as the simulated one from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. This behavior was also investigated for other solvents vapor such as methanol, ethanol, acetone, acetonitrile, dichloromethane, DMF and DMSO, but sensitive only with water vapor.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
To assess the thermal stability, TGA was recorded for the single-phase polycrystalline samples in the temperature range of 30-800°C. During the heating process, the TGA profile of 1 indicates the release of one coordinated water molecule at the first step of weight loss which is in the temperature range of 100-134°C (found, 3.81%; anal. calcd, 4.21%), resulting to the dehydrated form of Co(4,4'-bipy)(pro)2 (1A), which is stable up to ~215°C and then the structure rapidly decomposes at higher temperature, as shown in Fig. S4.

The dynamic structural behaviors of 1 relating to their dehydration and rehydration processes are studied by elemental analyses, XRPD, and spectroscopic techniques. When the single crystals of 1 were heated to 150°C in air for 20min, these crystals suddenly lose their crystallinity and the color changes from orange (1) to pink (1A). Then this non-crystalline solid was exposed to water vapor for 12h and the color of the solid 1A was returned to that of the original crystals 1', as shown in   and Fig. S5. For this, the solid-state UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra as shown in Fig. S6, clearly show that the bands observed in 1 and 1' correspond very well to the identical transitions causing the same color of products, and evidence that 1 and 1' have the same Co(II) environments. This spectral feature agrees with the typical d-d transitions of high spin Co(II) in distorted octahedral geometry with two broad bands at 471 and 1180nm, assigned to the ν3: 4T1g → 4T1g(P) and ν1: 4T1g → 4T2g, transitions, respectively . Whereas the amorphous form 1A shows different d-d transitions with three broad bands, ν3: 4T1g → 4T1g(P) which is splitted into two shoulders at around 484nm and 518nm (4Eg and 4A2g), ν2: 4T1g → 4A2g at 656nm and then ν1: 4T1g → 4T2g which is splitted into two shoulders at around 934nm and 1337nm (4B2g and 4Eg), giving the distinctive pink color and corresponding to the tetragonally distorted octahedral geometry . Furthermore, the IR spectra also confirm the structural transformation behavior in 1, as shown in Fig S7. In 1A, the broad and strong peaks of OH stretching around 3300cm-1 and HOH bending around 1500-1600cm-1 of coordinated water molecule disappear, resulting to the sharper IR spectrum with different splitting feature and a shift in some peak positions. In contrast, these features are removed in the IR spectrum of the rehydrated form 1', which are identical to that of the as-synthesized 1. The XRPD pattern of the as-synthesized product closely match the simulated one from the single-crystal data (Fig. S8). However, the XRPD pattern of dehydrated 1A shows peak disappearance, indicating that the dehydrated Co(4,4'-bipy)(pro)2 (1A) is in an amorphous phase (anal. calcd: C, 53.19; H, 5.02; N, 7.75%. Found: C, 52.26; H, 5.04; N, 7.61%) which is formed by the collapse of supramolecular structure of 1 accompanied with the destruction of hydrogen bonding networks when all water molecules are removed. Interestingly, this amorphous phase 1A can be restored to the original crystalline phase of 1' in which the color returns to that of the original color after being exposed in water vapor for 24h, as indicated by elemental analysis with the chemical composition of [Co(4,4'-bipy)(pro)2(H2O)] (1') (anal. calcd: C, 50.67; H, 5.32; N, 7.39%. Found: C, 50.34; H, 5.28; N, 7.42%) and the XRPD measurement results. The restored solid has the same XRPD pattern as the simulated one from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of 1. This behavior was also investigated for other solvents vapor such as methanol, ethanol, acetone, acetonitrile, dichloromethane, DMF and DMSO, but sensitive only with water vapor.

<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>, i<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>

<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>].</ce:simple-para>

(d) Crystal packing diagram of 3D supramolecular network, assembled by hydrogen bonding interactions. [Symmetry codes: A=-x, -y, -z; B=-x, 1/2-+y, 1/2-z; C= x, 1/2-y, 1/2+ z, i=2- x, 1- y, 1- z].

metadata.title: Flexible metal supramolecular framework of 2D cobalt(II) coordination polymer with water-induced reversible crystal-to-amorphous transformation
